thread.title_full: Chiefs form alliance with American Indian groups to educate fans - KCTV5

author: Chris Oberholtz, Multimedia Producer
title: Chiefs form alliance with American Indian groups to educate fans
text:
KANSAS CITY, MO (KCTV) - Chiefs fans often show their team spirit by dressing up for home games, but some things fans wear could be considered offensive to the Native American culture.
Kevin Peak has been coming to Kansas City Chiefs games for six years, and this season he added a new piece to his wardrobe.
"I want to represent our Chiefs well, and the head dress is the way to do it," he said.
But American Indian Center president John Learned says Peakâ€™s $40 garment can often be offensive to Native Americans.
"All of those feathers are earned, and as we want to preserve our culture, we want to respect it and we want others to respect it as well. But you can't respect something you don't understand," Learned said.
That is why for the second year in a row, they've partnered with the Chiefs for American Indian Heritage Month. The goal is to educate fans, like Peak, on ways to show their team spirit in a respectful way.
"Make fans aware of the traditional struggles of American Indians and some of the rituals and heritage that are uniquely indigenous to Native American people," said Bill Chapin, senior vice president of business operations for the Chiefs.
While Peak appreciates the education, he says he'll continue to wear his head dress.
"I don't think this was meant to be offensive. This is meant to stand by our team and to be part of everything," he said.
And Learned knows it will take time but hopes that with more education more understanding from fans will come.
"With a better understanding of how we feel as Native Americans, that change can happen and it will be good for everyone," he said.
Members of the American Indian Community Working Group participated in a number of moments before Sunday's game at Arrowhead, including the presentation of the colors.
The national anthem was performed by members of the Chicksaw Nation Youth Choir. A drum mallet was also presented to former Chiefs player Tony Gonzalez in addition to an honor song performed during the pregame. 
Tribes attending Sunday's game included Citizen Potawatomi Nation, Chickasaw Nation, Kaw Nation, Modoc Tribe, Peoria Tribe, Quapaw Tribe, Shawnee Tribe and Wyandotte Nation.
